title: U.S. Home Buyers During Market Crash Have Made More Than $200 Billion in Equity
text:
Whether savvy or lucky, U.S. home buyers who snapped up properties at the bottom of the last housing collapse have earned more than $200 billion in home equity since then, according to a report Thursday from property site Redfin.



Prices hit rock bottom in 2012, when the median U.S. home sold for $210,000, a number that has since surged to $320,000, Redfin’s median price estimate for September. Rising home values have been a boon to people who bought homes that year and who have since earned a median $141,000 in equity—quadruple their starting equity of $54,000, according to Redfin’s analysis of about 1.4 million home sales in 2012.



More: Frank Lloyd Wright’s Last Home Goes up For Auction

Homeowners gain equity as the amount they can sell their home for exceeds the amount they still owe on their mortgage.



Homeowners in major metropolitan areas, where home prices have soared in recent years, have banked the most in equity since 2012. No more so than in San Francisco, where median home equity has increased by a stunning $741,000 as the city’s median home values just about doubled since 2012, according to Redfin’s analysis.



Nine out of the top 10 cities for home equity growth since 2012 are in California, including tech-hub San Jose, where the typical home buyer from that year has seen their home equity increase by $669,000.



While cities have seen the greatest increase in dollar terms, smaller cities near U.S. military bases have seen the greatest percentage growth in home equity. For instance Tacoma, Washington, has seen the median equity of someone who purchased in 2012 skyrocket more than 1,400%.



That’s largely because these cities have high numbers of military personnel, who would have been able to take out a loan with no or little downpayment through Veteran Affairs or the Federal Housing Administration. In other words, these homebuyers started out with very little home equity.



“People in the military are able to obtain VA loans, and military buyers are also often able to obtain low interest rates. That turned out to be hugely beneficial for people in the area who bought homes in the wake of the recession," said Redfin agent Jordan Hammond, based in Virginia Beach, Virginia.



After Tacoma, Virginia Beach saw the second greatest percentage increase in home equity. The median homebuyer from 2012 has gained $80,000, a staggering increase of 1,333%.

While surging home prices have greatly benefited homeowners, it has kept many would-be buyers out of the housing market.

"The opportunity to build wealth through home equity when prices hit their low point was available only to a fortunate subset of Americans who had enough cash for a down payment," said Redfin chief economist Daryl Fairweather in the report. “And now many people who weren't able to buy into homeownership during that window of time find themselves on the other side of the housing market coin: Many areas are just plain unaffordable.”
